prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B4_1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: spectrroscopic survey in Band 4 for line and continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The spectral resolution is driven by the strongest lines in our line survey. We chose this resolution in order 1) not to miss unexpected narrow features, such as narrow emission (maser) or absorption, and 2) for the strong lines that have >10 times more flux than the weakest lines that we used for line S/N calculation. We also opted for this a little higher resolution for the line FWHM because data from different spectral windows, execution blocks, and science goals need to be put on a common frequency grid. This resolution minimize line-smearing in that process. For the same reason, we use a common spectral resolution even for spectral windwos without expected strong lines.

The target resolution of 0.2" is the approximate size of the molecular core at the nucleus of this galaxy (Sakamoto et al. 2013; Costagliola et al. 2013). We match our beam to this size for high beam-filling factor. The resolution also allows us to determine the size of the line core (i.e., extent of each line emitter) and the continuum core. The size of the line/continuum cores is one of the main key parameter of this nucleus, because from the size and flux density we obtain the brightness temperature that gives a lower limit to the physical temperature of the emitting medium. The largest angular scale of ~2" is the scale of the molecular envelope that is not visible in most lines (and in continuum). The CO total size is about 3" and the gas rotation makes its size smaller in each channel.

Continuum data will be taken only from line-free channels. We assume its total width to be 2 GHz in our 7 GHz band. The continuum data will be then used for visibility fitting. The continuum SN for 2GHz of ~500 is necessary for visibility fitting, because the RMS on each baseline (or group of baselines) is higher than the map RMS and signal on long baselines is weaker than the total source flux for this partially resolved target. Our 2GHz continuum S/N of ~300 in Band 4 is a compromize for realistic observing time. Each line gets narrower in frequency at lower frequencies. Hence we likely have more 'continuum' channel in Band 4. If we have 4 GHz in total then S/N ~ 420.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: spectroscopic survey in Band 7 for line and continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The spectral resolution is driven by the strongest lines in our line survey. We chose this resolution in order 1) not to miss unexpected narrow features, such as narrow emission (maser) or absorption, and 2) for the strong lines that have >10 times more flux than the weakest lines that we used for line S/N calculation. We also opted for this a little higher resolution for the line FWHM because data from different spectral windows, execution blocks, and science goals need to be put on a common frequency grid. This resolution minimize line-smearing in that process. For the same reason, we use a common spectral resolution even for spectral windwos without expected strong lines.

The target resolution of 0.2" is the approximate size of the molecular core at the nucleus of this galaxy (Sakamoto et al. 2013; Costagliola et al. 2013). We match our beam to this size for high beam-filling factor. The resolution also allows us to determine the size of the line core (i.e., extent of each line emitter) and the continuum core. The size of the line/continuum cores is one of the main key parameter of this nucleus, because from the size and flux density we obtain the brightness temperature that gives a lower limit to the physical temperature of the emitting medium. The largest angular scale of ~2" is the scale of the molecular envelope that is not visible in most lines (and in continuum). The CO total size is about 3" and the gas rotation makes its size smaller in each channel.

Continuum data will be taken only from line-free channels. We assume its total width to be 2 GHz in our 7 GHz band. The continuum data will be then used for visibility fitting. The continuum SN for 2GHz of ~500 is necessary for visibility fitting, because the RMS on each baseline (or group of baselines) is higher than the map RMS and signal on long baselines are weaker than the total source flux for this partially resolved target.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We propose a 160 GHz spectral scan through bands 4, 6, and 7 at 0.2" resolution toward the compact obscured nucleus of the luminous infrared galaxy NGC 4418. This extremely dust-enshrouded 1e11 Lsun nucleus is in a phase of rapid evolution, either as a Compton-thick AGN with a high-Eddington ratio or a very young compact starburst. This project will complete a 200 GHz scan started in Cycle 0 and use all the diagnostic power of molecular spectroscopy and astrochemistry to characterize the hidden nucleus. Most notably, lines from radiatively-pumped vibrationally excited molecules will be used to constrain the nature of the hidden radiation source. We will also use such solid physics and astronomy basis as Kepler and Stefan-Boltzmann laws and stellar L/M and AGN Eddington ratio to physically characterize the hidden nucleus. Specifically, we will measure the size and surface(brightness) temperature of the dust photosphere, derive the nuclear luminosity, and obtain L/M using a dynamical mass from gas kinematics. The L/M ratio will constrain the nature of the hidden nucleus because stars cannot have as high an L/M as an AGN can.
Seven of our 25 tunings are in the Cycle 2 queue.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00377.S "Fire and Wind in Compton-thick Monser: The Case of NGC 4418", K. Sakamoto et al. (Cycle 1. approved) 2011.0.00820.S "A 170 GHz-wide Complete Spectral Scan of an IR-pumped, Luminous Infrared Galaxy", F. Costagliola et al. (Cycle 0. approved)
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Academia Sinica
